dataset_info.name: Financial Cyber-Warfare Scenarios
dataset_info.description: High-complexity attack/defense scenarios focused on financial infrastructure (HFT, SWIFT, DeFi, Banking)

scenarios.title: Microsecond Latency Injection (Time-jacking)
scenarios.context: An HFT firm reports a consistent 4-millisecond discrepancy between their internal clock and the exchange execution report timestamps, correlating with a 15% loss in arbitrage opportunities. Network logs show sporadic ICMP anomalies.
objectives: Detect if the latency is artificial (attack) or structural
Identify the network hop responsible for the delay
Propose a mitigation strategy for time-synchronization (PTP/NTP) security
scenarios.system_prompt: You are NetPsyche, specializing in UEBA and Network anomalies. Analyze this micro-latency issue in an HFT environment. Focus on PTP (Precision Time Protocol) attacks and Front-Running detection.
golden_answer_points: PTP (IEEE 1588) delay attack identification
Analysis of 'Delay_Req' and 'Delay_Resp' message manipulation
Differentiation between network congestion and malicious queuing
Recommendation for separate physical synchronization network

scenarios.title: SWIFT Alliance Access Malware Injection
scenarios.context: Forensics reveals a suspicious binary 'libor_update.dll' injected into the SWIFT Alliance Access memory space. The binary hooks the 'mt103_validate' function but only activates during weekends.
objectives: Reverse engineer the DLL to understand the hooking mechanism
Determine how it modifies MT103 (Single Customer Credit Transfer) fields
Identify the exfiltration channel for the modified transaction logs
scenarios.system_prompt: You are RE-Automata, the Reverse Engineering Expert. Perform a static and dynamic analysis of this banking trojan via the provided pseudocode/assembly snippets. Identify the logic flow specifically targeting SWIFT message fields.
golden_answer_points: Identification of API Hooking (e.g., Detours or inline patching)
Modification of 'Beneficiary Account' field in MT103
Analysis of the specific date/time trigger (weekend execution)
Identification of steganographic exfiltration in PDF reports

scenarios.title: Flash Loan Reentrancy Attack
scenarios.context: A lending protocol on Ethereum has just lost $50M. The attacker used a Flash Loan to borrow assets, manipulated the internal price oracle, and drained the pool before repaying the loan in the same transaction.
objectives: Analyze the Solidity smart contract code for reentrancy vulnerabilities
Explain the sequence of calls (Borrow -> Attack -> Repay)
Write a patch to prevent the reentrancy or price manipulation
scenarios.system_prompt: You are VulnScout, specialized in Smart Contract auditing. Review the provided Solidity snippet. Trace the state changes and external calls. Propose a 'Checks-Effects-Interactions' pattern fix.
golden_answer_points: Use of 'nonReentrant' modifier
Implementation of Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern
Reliance on decentralized manipulat-resistant oracles (e.g., Chainlink) instead of internal spot price
Identification of logic error allowing withdraw before state update

scenarios.title: Dark Pool Insider Leak via Steganography
scenarios.context: A competitor consistently trades ahead of large block orders placed in your Dark Pool. No network leaks detected, but an employee posts daily 'motivational quotes' images on a public forum just before market open.
objectives: Analyze the image files for LSB (Least Significant Bit) steganography
Correlate image posting timestamps with block trade execution
Decrypt the hidden payload containing ticker symbols and volumes
scenarios.system_prompt: You are ForensicLens. Investigate this potential data exfiltration channel. Focus on Steganalysis techniques and correlation of non-technical signals (social media) with technical events (trades).
golden_answer_points: Application of StegExpose or similar LSB analysis tools
Extraction of hidden ASCII data from image noise
Statistical correlation between post times and trade volumes
Evidence preservation for legal (SEC/AMF) proceedings

scenarios.title: CBDC Consensus Sybil Attack
scenarios.context: A pilot CBDC (Central Bank Digital Currency) running on a permissioned ledger experiences a ledger fork. 35% of the validator nodes are rejecting valid transactions from specific commercial banks.
objectives: Simulate a Sybil attack on the consensus mechanism (PBFT/Raft)
Determine if the malicious nodes are colluding (Byzantine Fault)
Propose a hard-fork strategy to slash the malicious validators
scenarios.system_prompt: You are AdversarySim. Model this threat against a sovereign digital currency system. Evaluate the consensus resilience against a 33%+ attack vector. Design a recovery protocol.
golden_answer_points: Identification of Byzantine Fault Tolerance limits (usually 33% nodes)
Proof of collusion via signature timing analysis
Implementation of a 'Slashing Condition' in the protocol
Emergency fallback to centralized sequencer temporarily
